A pull request should be submitted targeting the main branch with relevant code changes, documentation updates, and before/after examples if possible.

issueDTO.title: Ubuntu Setup: Prereq script exits after path error
issueDTO.description:
## Bug report

**Issue details**

_When the script attempts to setup the environment at the end of the prerequisites installation process on Ubuntu, the script will fail to set $SCRIPT_DIR and $ARDUPILOT_ROOT if the name of the parent folder containing the Ardupilot repository contains a space character, e.g.:

`"../Drone Projects/ardupilot/Tools..."`

The following error occurs and causes the script to exit prior to completion:

```
+ echo '##############################################'
##############################################
+ echo Adding ArduPilot Tools to environment
Adding ArduPilot Tools to environment
+ echo '##############################################'
##############################################
+++ realpath Tools/environment_install/install-prereqs-ubuntu.sh
++ dirname /home/agstewart/Desktop/Drone Projects/ardupilot/Tools/environment_install/install-prereqs-ubuntu.sh
+ SCRIPT_DIR='/home/agstewart/Desktop
Projects/ardupilot/Tools/environment_install'
++ realpath '/home/agstewart/Desktop
Projects/ardupilot/Tools/environment_install/../../'
realpath: '/home/agstewart/Desktop'$'\n''Projects/ardupilot/Tools/environment_install/../../': No such file or directory
+ ARDUPILOT_ROOT=
agstewart@dev:~/Desktop/Drone Projects/ardupilot$
```

**Version**
_built from source on master branch_

**Platform**
[ x] All
comments: Obvious solution is to rename the folder, but I figured that this is still a problem so it should be reported.

thanks for the report.

Yes this would need some fixing to handle better the path. would you like to make a PR to fix it ?

issueDTO.title: Permissions: Put ellipsis to avoid text wrapping
issueDTO.description:
## Bug Description

Currently, the text wraps when the name of the workspace gets too long. This causes alignment problems visually. In addition, on the "Object-Level Permissions" the name currently is "See Record on Companies."

**Example:** 

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/5c44ca8d-5cfe-4427-ba83-fdfe32f9e454)

## Expected behavior

Instead, we want to add ellipsis when the line gets too long to avoid the wrapping from happening and change naming structure to [Action] + [Object Name] (e.g. "See Companies"). This will also allow more space for the description. 

[Figma link](https://www.figma.com/design/xt8O9mFeLl46C5InWwoMrN/Twenty?node-id=67064-202199&t=7FpVe9aghO3pD220-1)

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d832d4d2-8420-4d1f-8a1d-72b8ad167e9c)

issueDTO.title: Scroll main panel by whole pages?
issueDTO.description:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**


I'm used to using `git diff`, where I have to do <kbd>f</kbd> and <kbd>b</kbd> to scroll up/down whole pages.

I'd like to scroll up/down the main panel multiple pages in the same way for the same reason.


**Describe the solution you'd like**

I tried Ctrl-PgUp/Down and Shift-etc and they did not work. Could these be used?

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

Just dealing with it, but then I thought: why not post a feature request?

**Additional context**

Cool program everyone. Thanks for making it!
comments:
I like the sound of ctrl+pgup/pgdown. If that's actually a thing that we can send to the terminal then I'm on board.

f and b are already used for various keybindings so I'm hesitant to use those.

I'll chuck a good-first-issue label on this. If anybody wants to take a stab, you can search for `scrollUpMain` in the codebase to see how that works. We need versions of `scrollUpView` and `scrollDownView` in `pkg/gui/global_handlers.go` that take the scroll amount as a parameter, rather than hardcoding to use `gui.UserConfig.Gui.ScrollHeight` internally. Then we can pass them the height of the view as that parameter to have us scrolling by a whole page.
btw @sdegutis if you want to get your hands dirty with Go, this would be a good first start!
Sorry, to clarify, I'm requesting we use <kbd>Shift-PageUp</kbd> and <kbd>Shift-PageDown</kbd> (or Ctrl-).
Tbh I mainly solved this by just setting scroll amount to 10 in config instead of the default of 2 and using the mouse wheel to scroll, so this can be closed if you want.
By the way @jesseduffield when I looked through the src earlier, I was surprised this was written in Go. I assumed it was written using https://www.npmjs.com/package/blessed

Happy to keep this issue open as others have asked about it (even I would like it haha).

Yeah my choice to use Go was really just coincidence because I wanted to learn the language
So how do you like Go after learning it?

First of all Awesome tool!

Based on my understanding of https://github.com/jesseduffield/lazygit/issues/1707#issuecomment-1017947410 I have created a PR to try and implement this -> https://github.com/jesseduffield/lazygit/pull/1709

I had to use `Alt+f` to scroll up a page and `Alt+b` to scroll down a page since I was not able to figure out how to use other modifiers like `Shift` or `Ctrl`

@jesseduffield I agree, I came to that conclusion maybe 7 years ago. I tried Rust out and I guess it's fine if you need low-level and lightning-fast and ultra-safe code, which I do 0% of the time (and apparently neither does VS Code but it works well enough). I'm going to try my hand at a quick Electron git client in TypeScript one of these days using [simple-git](https://www.npmjs.com/package/simple-git).

I also vote for hotkeys for whole page scrolling. `C-f/C-b` (like manpage)  and `C-u/C-d` (like tig) both feels right to me. It should be configurable so there should just be a default one and let users choose what they like.
@jesseduffield -- any update on this one? It'd be really lovely to be able to scroll by whole pages.

As of v0.50 you can now focus the main view (by pressing `0`), and then you can navigate it using all the normal navigation keys like `.` and `,` for scrolling by page, or `<` and `>` for beginning/end.

Given that we do now have a way of scrolling the main view both by line and by page via focusing it, I wonder if we should update the page-up/page-down keys to actually scroll by page now. Seems like lots of people are surprised that it currently defaults to only scrolling by line.

On the other hand, lots of lazygit users (myself included) have become accustomed to page-up/page-down only scrolling by lines

As a vim user, I'm accustomed to `ctrl+u` and `ctrl+d` scrolling by _half pages_, and that is what I expected in the lazygit diff view (instead, it scrolls one line, just like pg up/dn). I'm very much in favor of making these scroll by page in the diff view. 

When I'm staging files for a commit, I'd like to quickly move from file to file, while being able to scroll quickly in the diff without having to switch focus back and forth between the panes. 

Ideally, scrolling by line should also be available somehow in this view. One suggestion would be to use `ctrl+e` and `ctrl+y` to scroll by line, just like in vim, however, I see that `ctrl+e` is already in use. `ctrl+j` and `ctrl+k` could also be agreeable, and seems to be available.
We could also scroll alternative views by alt+down/up or ctrl+down/up

I think a modifier + any-navigation keys applying to the current view would be good.

`ctrl + ,` or `ctrl + .` applying to current view would be great. I also think we should have an alternative for line scrolling on the current view, page-up/down should really do what they say on the box imo.

... I should really offer a PR rather than my opinion

> As of v0.50 you can now focus the main view (by pressing `0`), and then you can navigate it using all the normal navigation keys like `.` and `,` for scrolling by page, or `<` and `>` for beginning/end.

Thanks, that's perfect!

This feature is similar to the behavior in `git diff`, where users can scroll up and down by whole pages using `Ctrl-PgUp/PgDown` or `Shift-PgUp/PgDown`.

This function can then be used to scroll the main panel by whole pages.
summary.otherNotes: This issue is about adding a feature to scroll the main panel by whole pages, similar to the behavior in `git diff`. The contributor is requesting the use of `Ctrl-PgUp/PgDown` or `Shift-PgUp/PgDown` to scroll up and down the main panel. issueDTO.title: Idea: add GitHub usernames to `PackageInfo.g` to `Persons` records
issueDTO.description:
For automation of the package distribution, it would be useful to have the GitHub username of package maintainers in the `PackageInfo.g`. E.g. add an optional field `GitHubUsername` to the `Persons` records.

To be clear, to do this, we basically should do this:
- mention it in the ref manual section on packages
- add it to the example package, and document it there as well (via a comment in `PackageInfo.g` file)

Some bonus objectives:
- enhance [`PackageMaker`](https://github.com/gap-system/PackageMaker) to produce this field (at least if the user chose to create a GitHub repository?)
- modify packages to use it
- modify the [`PackageDistro `](https://github.com/gap-system/PackageDistro) scripts to use it
comments:
If I remember correctly, you gave a bit more information about your motivation at the GAP Days:

Suppose that the `PackageInfo.g` file for a package contained the GitHub username of one or more maintainers. This would allow an automated script to automatically 'ping' (by using @`GitHubUsername`) these people in a GitHub comment, at an appropriate point. For instance, this could happen when a new version of a package is added to the package distribution, or when a certain automated test fails for a package. This isn't something we could easily do by email.

I would be happy for my GitHub username to be included into the `PackageInfo.g` files of the packages to which I contribute.

Does this actually require any technical change to GAP, or does it just require people to start doing it?
Just requires us doing it (well, and agreeing where to out it). And ideally mentioning it in docs for the package format
I think we should do this, in the event we ever more away from github, we can of course at that point change to different names.
I support this too

summary.validationOrRequirement: The expected behavior is for the GitHub username of package maintainers to be included in the `PackageInfo.g` file, allowing for automated scripts to 'ping' these people in a GitHub comment. This feature should be implemented to enhance the automation of the package distribution.

issueDTO.title: [Feature Request] Intable should not inherit Copyable or Movable
issueDTO.description:
### Review Mojo's priorities

- [x] I have read the [roadmap and priorities](https://docs.modular.com/mojo/roadmap.html#overall-priorities) and I believe this request falls within the priorities.

### What is your request?

`Intable` currently inherits from `Copyable` and `Moveable` and I don't really see any reason why it should. Interestingly, `IntableRaising` doesn't inherit from them so it really seems like `Intable` shouldn't either.

### What is your motivation for this change?

I have a type I want to be `Intable` but not `Copyable`.

### Any other details?

_No response_
comments: +1 to this, `Intable` shouldn't inherit from either `Copyable` or `Movable`.  I'd happily welcome a PR if anyone is interested at poking at this.  It may not "just work" and we'll have to re-discover the original reasons it was added.
Turns out it indeed "just work".

issueDTO.title: Allow Users to Share Feedback
issueDTO.description:
Implement a standalone FeedbackModule system that lets users submit their thoughts on puzzles, the app experience, or educational content. Users can choose to remain anonymous. Admins should have full access to view and manage all submitted feedback.

---

#### ✅ Tasks:

* Create a `Feedback` entity with the following fields:

  * `id`: primary key
  * `rating`: number (1–5)
  * `comment`: string (optional)
  * `targetType`: enum (`Puzzle`, `App`, `Education`)
  * `isAnonymous`: boolean (default: false)
  * `createdAt`: timestamp
* Create a POST endpoint: `/feedback`

  * Accepts feedback with or without user info (depending on `isAnonymous`)
* Create a GET endpoint: `/feedback/admin`

  * Accessible only by admins
  * Returns all feedback entries
comments: I'd like to work on this issue as I'm experienced with NestJS and backend APIs. I plan to create a standalone FeedbackModule with POST and admin-only GET endpoints, handling both anonymous and user-attached feedback as described. Excited to contribute!

issueDTO.title: Support request ro HTTPS oauth proxy sidecar
issueDTO.description:
In the environments with oauth-proxy as as reverse proxy to authenticate users (like OpenShift), the command fails. Neither with `--use-proxy`, not without it.

### Setup
- An opencost pod with a sidecar container having image `quay.io/openshift/origin-oauth-proxy:4.10.0` as an oauth-proxy which listens on 8443, checks users authorization with kubernetes SAR and proxies to `localhost:9090`
- A service with `clusterIP` type which maps port 443 on service to 8443 on pod

### Logs

Command which failed **with `--use-proxy`**:

```shell
kubectl cost --service-name opencost --kubecost-namespace costs --allocation-path /allocation/compute label -l team --window 1d --service-port 443 --log-level debug --use-proxy
```

Output
```
2023-10-18T18:23:24.493238+03:30 DBG failed to get currency code, displaying as empty string: failed to proxy get kubecost. err: the server is currently unable to handle
the request (get services opencost:ƻ); data: {"kind":"Status","apiVersion":"v1","metadata":{},"status":"Failure","message":"no endpoints available for service \"spc
ld-opencost:ƻ\"","reason":"ServiceUnavailable","code":503}

Error: failed to query allocation API: failed to proxy get kubecost. err: the server rejected our request for an unknown reason (get services opencost:443); data: C
lient sent an HTTP request to an HTTPS server.
```

Command which failed **without `--use-proxy`**:

```shell
kubectl cost --service-name opencost --kubecost-namespace costs --allocation-path /allocation/compute label -l team --window 1d --service-port 8443 --log-level debug
```

Output
```
2023-10-18T18:15:41.18618+03:30 DBG checking readiness of 'opencost-5766b5f4bb-vtnqn'
2023-10-18T18:15:41.186484+03:30 DBG selected pod to forward: opencost-5766b5f4bb-vtnqn
2023-10-18T18:15:41.334582+03:30 DBG Port-forward set up at: http://localhost:60877
2023-10-18T18:15:41.335083+03:30 DBG Executing GET to: http://localhost:60877/model/getConfigs
2023-10-18T18:15:42.463207+03:30 DBG failed to get currency code, displaying as empty string: failed to forward get kubecost: received non-200 status code 400 and data: C
lient sent an HTTP request to an HTTPS server.

2023-10-18T18:15:42.463384+03:30 DBG Executing GET to: http://localhost:60877/allocation/compute?accumulate=true&aggregate=cluster%2Clabel%3Ateamteam&window=1
d
Error: failed to query allocation API: failed to port forward query: received non-200 status code 400 and data: Client sent an HTTP request to an HTTPS server.
```

> This command's parameter `--service-port` has been set to `8443` due to failure. Seems it points to pod's port, not service's port in `port-forward` mode according to the logs:
> ```
> 2023-10-18T18:15:41.186484+03:30 DBG selected pod to forward: opencost-5766b5f4bb-vtnqn
> 2023-10-18T18:15:41.334582+03:30 DBG Port-forward set up at: http://localhost:60877
> ```

### Suggestion
I think there are two solutions might resolve this:
- Provide an option to send request directly to the opencost/kubecost API server (#128)
- Provide an option to send request as HTTPS to the `service-port`, with optionally pass CA. This method is different from first one, and might have other use cases, and eliminates need to expose the cost API publicly.
comments:
Thank you for the clear, detailed issue report and suggested approaches. I'm a bit swamped at the moment, but I'm always willing to review contributions if you'd like this functionality soon -- I'd be particularly amenable to a community contribution of "Provide an option to send request as HTTPS to the `service-port`, with optionally pass CA" because I see it as a relatively small change with high impact.

cc @kwombach12 so you're aware.
Hello! I'd like to pick this up if it's still needed.

issueDTO.title: KVstore GetKeys task - missclassified properties
issueDTO.description:
### Describe the issue

io.kestra.plugin.core.kv.GetKeys task should have Namespace & Prefix required.

### Environment

- Kestra Version: 

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/b6606a9d-64ec-4497-a62a-3be62a6ea28a)
comments:
Prefix is not mandatory but namespace is with a default value.
It's a frontend issue.

Same here, passed to UI as `required: false` @loicmathieu 

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/5bcf912a-9fe9-4048-93ed-e375c05438e2)

@MilosPaunovic hum it seems when a property is mandatory but there is a default value we set it to non-mandatory in the schema. This is tricky. If we don't do that, users would need to set a value, we may need to add a specific property for that...

Indeed, agree with @loicmathieu:

- prefix is not required
- namespace should be, but it has default value set to "{{ flow.namespace }}" which makes it nonmandatory from a user/flow perspective

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c97b6abe-2708-4c69-85f8-a9e92131b9a1)

Willing to close the issue; @loicmathieu what do you have in mind with "a specific property"?

>This is tricky. If we don't do that, users would need to set a value, we may need to add a specific property for that...

Is it about suggesting adding an explicit metadata field (e.g., implicitRequired, computedDefault, or userOptional) to differentiate between:
- Truly optional fields (user can omit, no impact).
- Fields with defaults that satisfy backend needs but are conceptually required (namespace in our case)
- Fields where omission leads to errors unless a default is defined.
Yes

Hi, I'm Shobhit. I want to take this up as my first contribution. From what I understand, the `namespace` field has a default (`{{ flow.namespace }}`) but is still conceptually required, which makes the UI schema a bit misleading.

Maybe we could handle this via a frontend-specific property like `implicitRequired` to reflect required-but-defaulted fields?

Please let me know what you think. 🙂
Would the above be a good approach in you opinion @loicmathieu?

to keep up with latest rust edition we need to update rust to 2024

update rust edition and code to support `edition = "2024`

issueDTO.title: Add test for prioritization scheme depends on in-order progress
issueDTO.description:
Our prioritization scheme depends on in-order progress in the order of creation.  It's not fatal, but we've always assumed that this is in-order.  Otherwise, you get bytes in an indeterminate order.  In particular, we don't tend to adjust priority of control streams in HTTP.

_Originally posted by @martinthomson in https://github.com/mozilla/neqo/pull/2764#discussion_r2174390238_

repository.description: Neqo, the Mozilla Firefox implementation of QUIC in Rust
repository.name: neqo

summary.main: The issue is that the prioritization scheme depends on in-order progress in the order of creation, which is not currently handled. This can lead to bytes being received in an indeterminate order, affecting the overall functionality of the system.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The expected behavior is for the prioritization scheme to correctly prioritize bytes in the order of creation, ensuring that bytes are not received in an indeterminate order.
summary.attemptedFixes: The fix can be implemented by adding a test case to ensure the prioritization scheme correctly handles in-order progress, possibly involving adjustments to the HTTP control streams.
summary.otherNotes: This issue is currently labeled as 'help wanted' and 'good first issue', indicating it's a suitable task for a contributor to tackle.

issueDTO.title: [RFC]: Unit test coverage improvement
issueDTO.description:
### Motivation

This issue attempt to reduce the gap of unit tests to cover the code. There is a brief architecture of ut in `tests/ut/` already. We need to add more to cover all the code in vllm-ascend, and there are several principles to follow:

1. The overall file tree should be consistent with `vllm_ascend`
2. The file name should be the original file name with a prefix `test_`
3. Use `unittest` framework, make good use of mock
4. The UTs are all running on cpu node, mock the function related to device to host

issueDTO.title: Bump `go-billy` and `go-git-fixtures`
issueDTO.description:
The replace directive can now be dropped and the direct dependencies can be bumped. That would involve:
- Drop the [replace directive](https://github.com/go-git/go-git/blob/20c25df268c3b144c573567cfabdca3685b365c2/go.mod#L9-L12).
- Bump all references from `go-billy/v5` to `go-billy/v6`.
- Bump to the latest pseudo commit of `go-billy/v6` from the `main` branch.
- Bump `go-git-fixtures` to the latest released version.
comments: Hi, newbie here, can I give it a try ?
Hey @codechamp1, thanks for giving it a go. I'm assigning this to you.

Hey @pjbgf,

just to make sure I understand it right, `go-billy` should be updated to the latest `v6` version and `go-git-fixtures` to the latest `v5` version, yes ?
@codechamp1 that's correct. `go-billy` doesn't have a cut version for `v6` yet, so it will need to be a pseudo version from `main` (e.g. `go get github.com/go-git/go-billy/v6@main`.

repository.description: A highly extensible Git implementation in pure Go.
repository.name: go-git

summary.main: The issue is about bumping `go-billy` and `go-git-fixtures` to the latest versions, which involves dropping the replace directive and updating the dependencies to ensure the project remains maintainable.

issueDTO.title: Idempotency issue with YAML tags used in sequences
issueDTO.description:
## What version of OpenRewrite are you using?

Current main = 46a4761b1833cc82e2c1c594c6e0933adcf2d1e8

## What is the smallest, simplest way to reproduce the problem?

The following unit test case:
```java
    @Test
    void tagsInSequences() {
        rewriteRun(
          yaml(
            """
            Conditions:
              IsPollingFrequencyInMinutesSingular: !Equals [!Ref PollingFrequencyInMinutes, 1]
            """
          )
        );
    }
```
fails with:
```diff
  Conditions:
-   IsPollingFrequencyInMinutesSingular: !Equals [!Ref PollingFrequencyInMinutes, 1]
+   IsPollingFrequencyInMinutesSingular: !Equals [ !Equals !Ref PollingFrequencyInMinutes, 1]
```

## Context

- Must be some case not taken into account in #4934.
- Extracted from real-life: https://github.com/awslabs/aws-serverless-twitter-event-source/blob/24f821a2d45959b2691bbf63f71ce9bc1094ec7e/template.yml#L34-L35
comments:
As far as I can tell this is caused by the tag being both attached to the sequence but also included in the startBracketPrefix.
The startBracketPrefix renders the tag in the expected location but the tag attached to the sequence renders inside the square brackets.

The below code change to YamlParser L380 resolves the test provided with no regression within rewrite-yaml
`if (sse.getTag() != null && startBracketPrefix == null) {`

However this feels incorrect and a bit of a bodge and not confident enough in my Yaml syntax knowledge to spot the edge case!
Any pointer much appreciated

repository.name: rewrite

summary.main: The issue is about idempotency problems with YAML tags used in sequences. The provided unit test case fails and shows the expected and actual output, highlighting the problem. summary.validationOrRequirement: The expected behavior is for the YAML tags used in sequences to be correctly rendered without causing idempotency issues. The issue needs to be fixed to ensure that the tags are properly handled and do not interfere with the sequence.
summary.attemptedFixes: The fix can be implemented by modifying the YamlParser at line 380 to handle the tag being both attached to the sequence and included in the startBracketPrefix. The provided code change suggests adding a condition to check if the tag is not null and the startBracketPrefix is null.
summary.otherNotes: This issue is labeled as 'bug', 'parser-yaml', 'test provided', and 'good first issue', indicating it's a significant issue suitable for a contributor to tackle. A pull request should be submitted targeting the main branch with before/after screenshots or video if possible.

issueDTO.title: Bot prevention : IP limit filter
issueDTO.description:
[Version française (google translate)]()

### Problem

- Some bot are grabbing us. Ok, that's not a big problem, we are quiet open ;) 
-  but we have to provide some "bot access control" features, to prevent fronts and backs outages
- we will also need this kind of feature for the B2B API 

### Solution

- Implement a cool spring filter, that allows a MAX_REQUEST_PER_IP limit, that whitelist known bots, ...
- Will redirect to a captcha protected page (done in #315 ) to reinit the counter in case when limits are reached 

### Requisites

-  must be a generic and well documented mechanism, to be able to use it easily in new controlers / endpoints that must be bot protected. 
- must be configurable, with limits (count and time window)
- must provides a IP whitelisting mechanism , to inject authorized engines ips (bots adress will be handled in a separate service )
- must provides a IP blacklisting mechanism , to inject forbidden engines ips (bots adress will be handled in a separate service )

- should be a spring approach, or something that can easily be applied in spring context

### Tips /  work tracks

- Can have a look at the commented commons/src/main/java/org/open4goods/filter/QuotasFilter.java, a old legacy implementation of this kind of stuf
- maybe something exists, or could be a new, separate spring boot starter project ?

issueDTO.title: [ACTION] Extend Vertex AI MCP server with Veo3 support
issueDTO.description:
I just checked it out and Vertex AI supports Veo3 through API. It would be great if you could support this as well through your MCP server. I'm talking about the MCP server with slug google_vertex_ai. 

I played around with some example code which may be helpful. Below a script on how to use the vertex api to generate Veo3 videos:



################################################################################
import os
import time
import urllib.request
from dotenv import load_dotenv

from google import genai
from google.genai import types

# Load environment variables
load_dotenv()




def save_video_locally(video_data, output_dir="./generated_videos", filename=None):
    """
    Saves video data (bytes or URL) to a local file.
    """
    # Create output directory if it doesn't exist
    os.makedirs(output_dir, exist_ok=True)
    
    # Generate filename if not provided
    if not filename:
        filename = f"video_{int(time.time())}.mp4"
    filepath = os.path.join(output_dir, filename)
    
    if isinstance(video_data, bytes):
        # Save video bytes directly
        with open(filepath, 'wb') as f:
            f.write(video_data)
        print(f"Video saved to: {filepath}")
    elif isinstance(video_data, str) and video_data.startswith('http'):
        # Download from URL
        urllib.request.urlretrieve(video_data, filepath)
        print(f"Video downloaded and saved to: {filepath}")
    else:
        print(f"Unsupported video data type: {type(video_data)}")
        return None
    
    return filepath



def generate_video_from_text(client, prompt, enhance_prompt=True, generate_audio=True):
    """
    Generate videos from a text prompt.
    
    Args:
        client: The genai client instance
        prompt: A detailed description of the video you would like to see
        enhance_prompt: Whether to enhance the provided prompt
        generate_audio: Whether to include audio in the output video
    
    Returns:
        The operation result if successful, None otherwise
    """

    video_model = "veo-3.0-generate-preview"
    
    operation = client.models.generate_videos(
        model=video_model,
        prompt=prompt,
        config=types.GenerateVideosConfig(
            aspect_ratio="16:9",
            number_of_videos=1,
            duration_seconds=8,
            person_generation="allow_adult",
            enhance_prompt=enhance_prompt,
            generate_audio=generate_audio,
        ),
    )
    
    while not operation.done:
        time.sleep(15)
        operation = client.operations.get(operation)
        print(f"Operation status: {operation.name}")
    
    print(f"Operation completed. Done: {operation.done}")
    print(f"Operation object: {operation}")
    
    if hasattr(operation, 'error') and operation.error:
        print(f"Error generating video: {operation.error}")
        return None
    
    if hasattr(operation, 'result'):
        print(f"Has result: {operation.result}")
        if operation.result and hasattr(operation.result, 'generated_videos') and operation.result.generated_videos:
            video = operation.result.generated_videos[0].video
            if hasattr(video, 'uri') and video.uri:
                print(f"Video generated successfully (URI): {video.uri}")
            elif hasattr(video, 'video_bytes') and video.video_bytes:
                print(f"Video generated successfully (bytes): {len(video.video_bytes)} bytes")
            else:
                print(f"Video generated but no URI or bytes found")
            return operation.result
    
    print("No video was generated in the result")
    return None


def generate_video_from_image(client, prompt, image_path_or_url, enhance_prompt=True, generate_audio=True):
    """
    Generate videos from an image with optional text prompt.
    
    Args:
        client: The genai client instance
        prompt: Optional prompt to direct movement and audio
        image_path_or_url: Local path or URL of the input image
        enhance_prompt: Whether to enhance the provided prompt
        generate_audio: Whether to include audio in the output video
    
    Returns:
        The operation result if successful, None otherwise
    """
    video_model = "veo-3.0-generate-preview"




    operation = client.models.generate_videos(
        model=video_model,
        prompt=prompt,
        image=types.Image(
            gcs_uri=image_path_or_url if image_path_or_url.startswith("gs://") else None,
            uri=image_path_or_url if image_path_or_url.startswith("http") else None,
            mime_type="image/png",
        ),
        config=types.GenerateVideosConfig(
            aspect_ratio="16:9",
            number_of_videos=1,
            duration_seconds=8,
            person_generation="allow_adult",
            enhance_prompt=enhance_prompt,
            generate_audio=generate_audio,
        ),
    )
    
    while not operation.done:
        time.sleep(15)
        operation = client.operations.get(operation)
        print(f"Operation status: {operation.name}")
    
    print(f"Operation completed. Done: {operation.done}")
    print(f"Operation object: {operation}")
    
    if hasattr(operation, 'error') and operation.error:
        print(f"Error generating video: {operation.error}")
        return None
    
    if hasattr(operation, 'result'):
        print(f"Has result: {operation.result}")
        if operation.result and hasattr(operation.result, 'generated_videos') and operation.result.generated_videos:
            video = operation.result.generated_videos[0].video
            if hasattr(video, 'uri') and video.uri:
                print(f"Video generated successfully (URI): {video.uri}")
            elif hasattr(video, 'video_bytes') and video.video_bytes:
                print(f"Video generated successfully (bytes): {len(video.video_bytes)} bytes")
            else:
                print(f"Video generated but no URI or bytes found")
            return operation.result
    
    print("No video was generated in the result")
    return None


def main():
    """
    Main function to demonstrate Veo 3 video generation.
    """
    # Set your project configuration from environment variables
    PROJECT_ID = os.environ.get("GOOGLE_CLOUD_PROJECT")
    if not PROJECT_ID or PROJECT_ID == "your-project-id":
        raise ValueError("Please set GOOGLE_CLOUD_PROJECT in your .env file")
    
    LOCATION = os.environ.get("GOOGLE_CLOUD_REGION", "us-central1")
    LOCAL_OUTPUT_DIR = os.environ.get("LOCAL_OUTPUT_DIR", "./generated_videos")
    
    print(f"Using project: {PROJECT_ID}")
    print(f"Using region: {LOCATION}")
    print(f"Videos will be saved to: {LOCAL_OUTPUT_DIR}")
    print(f"Note: Veo 3 API may only be available in us-central1. If you get errors, try changing GOOGLE_CLOUD_REGION to us-central1 in your .env file.")
    
    # Check for credentials
    print("\nChecking Google Cloud authentication...")
    print("To authenticate, you need to run one of these commands:")
    print("1. For user account: gcloud auth application-default login")
    print("2. For service account: Set GOOGLE_APPLICATION_CREDENTIALS in .env to point to your service account key file")
    print("")
    
    # Create client
    client = genai.Client(vertexai=True, project=PROJECT_ID, location=LOCATION)
    
    # Example 1: Generate video from text prompt
    print("Generating video from text prompt...")
    text_prompt = "a garden gnome singing a pop song in a whimsical outdoor garden"
    
    result = generate_video_from_text(client, text_prompt)
    if result:
        video = result.generated_videos[0].video
        if hasattr(video, 'uri') and video.uri:
            save_video_locally(video.uri, LOCAL_OUTPUT_DIR)
        elif hasattr(video, 'video_bytes') and video.video_bytes:
            save_video_locally(video.video_bytes, LOCAL_OUTPUT_DIR)
        else:
            print("No video URI or bytes found in result")
    
    # # Example 2: Generate video from image
    # print("\nGenerating video from image...")
    # image_prompt = "zoom out of the flower field, play whimsical music"
    # # You can use a URL or local path for the image
    # image_url = "https://storage.googleapis.com/cloud-samples-data/generative-ai/image/flowers.png"
    # 
    # result2 = generate_video_from_image(client, image_prompt, image_url)
    # if result2:
    #     video_url = result2.generated_videos[0].video.uri
    #     save_video_locally(video_url, LOCAL_OUTPUT_DIR)


if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

issueDTO.title: Add support for multiple outputs/inputs
issueDTO.description:
<!--- Provide a general summary of the issue in the Title above -->

## Detailed Description
The code as it is currently does take multiple graphs at once, and can outputs multiple graphs, along the batch dimension though. Having multiple inputs, such as for the NWP forecast grid + raw observations to generate the next analysis grid to more closely match how analysis files are actually generated could be helpful. Additionally, multiple outputs would be helpful, for example for #20 to output both the next NWP state and satellite image, potentially at different resolutions (i.e. HRV vs non-HRV channels for EUMETSAT), or for having more dense local outputs, it could be the global graph, and a local graph output in the decoder.

## Context
<!--- Why is this change important to you? How would you use it? -->
<!--- How can it benefit other users? -->

## Possible Implementation
Update the latent graph processor to take multiple encoders. Multple outputs can be achieved by taking the output from the graph processor and giving it as inputs into multiple decoders. There would just need to be a way to give multiple decoder configs to the overall model.

issueDTO.title: explore capturing of librbd logs when using go-ceph apis
issueDTO.description:
# Describe the feature you'd like to have #
We need to explore how we can capture librbd logs when using go-ceph apis to execute ceph rbd commands.
This would allow us to gather more details related to rbd commands and help in smoother debugging in case of any issues.

# What is the value to the end user? (why is it a priority?) #

With the librbd logs available we would be able to pinpoint issues in ceph rbd easily by backtracking the logs and helping the ceph rbd team to identify the issues easily.

ceph.conf: |

    rbd_validate_pool = false
    log_to_stderr = true
    debug_rbd = 20

We can also enable the librbd logs in the `csi-rbdplugin` container by executing the commands in the toolbox. This works for both rook+csi and ceph-csi-op+csi setup.
```
ceph config set global debug_rbd 30
ceph config set global log_to_stderr true
```

_P.S: It doesn't require any restart as well_ 😉

issueDTO.title: Shortcuts pane: "root" label in "run as root" mode
issueDTO.description:
# Introduction
Welcome to the project, if you pick up this Issue because of the "GOOD FIRST USE" label. You will be mentored through the process if you want. First the Issue is explained. At the end you will find some guidance for first contributors. Please do not hesitate to ask questions. Your solution don't need to be perfect.

Participation or contribution is not recommended unless you are familiar with Back In Time and are an active user. This project is not intended for learning basic Python skills or enhancing your profile at Microsoft GitHub.

# Problem & suggested solution
In the Shortcuts pane, there is Root and Home that open the respective content lists. When BiT is run as user, it points to the user's home folder, which is fine. Run as root, "Home" points to root's home folder, which is also fine, but the name is misleading here. It would be more clear to rename that pointer to "Root" or "/root". To avoid confusion of `/` "Root" and `/root` "Root", what is now "Root" (`/`) ought to be named more specifically, e.g. "Filesystem" or "Root Filesystem" or "Filesystem Root". If space is at a premium, omit the icons.

# Your next steps
1. If this is your first contribution in this project please introduce your self and tell us about your skills, wishes and plans. Also let us know how you found the issue and the project.
2. Read the existing [contributors documentation](https://github.com/bit-team/backintime/blob/dev/CONTRIBUTING.md).
3. We can develop the next steps in the further discussion. Don't hesitate to ask.

# Original post

Two cosmetic points that might make their way into a general GUI overhaul.

- Get rid of that pesky "Main profile". The name is not meaningful and not editable, so one has to take notes what that profile actually does, or disable it altogether. Still when the GUI is launched, "Main profile" is opened first and complains if it can't find its backup folder. That in turn can be mitigated with a dummy backup folder that is always available (I use `/root/.backintime-dummy/` and  `/home/user/.backintime-dummy/`), but this is an ugly situation. I guess "Main profile" is a leftover from very early days of BiT when it had a more limited functionality. It' done it's job and can go now.

- In the Shortcuts pane, there is Root and Home that open the respective content lists. When BiT is run as user, it points to the user's home folder, which is fine. Run as root, "Home" points to root's home folder, which is also fine, but the name is misleading here. It would be more clear to rename that pointer to "Root" or "/root". To avoid confusion of `/` "Root" and `/root` "Root", what is now "Root" (`/`) ought to be named more specifically, e.g. "Filesystem" or "Root Filesystem" or "Filesystem Root". If space is a premium, omit the icons.
comments:
Hello noyannus,

Thank you for taking the time to report and providing the details. I appreciate your feedback.

Your first point (about "Main profile") is covered by this issues:
- #1495
- #1371

Your second point about "root" in the shortcuts pane also does make sense. I edit your initial post to make it more clear for new contributors.

Best regards,

The edit is fine for me. You might also consider for BiT a visual marker to clearly show whether it runs as root or not. The menu bar holds enough space for a center aligned "Running as root" or so, possibly in red or bold font.

issueDTO.title: `.injectWS()` should auto register `ws.on("ping", () => ws.pong())`
issueDTO.description:
### Prerequisites

- [x] I have written a descriptive issue title
- [x] I have searched existing issues to ensure the bug has not already been reported


### Fastify version

5.2.1

### Plugin version

11.0.2

### Node.js version

22.14.0

### Operating system

macOS

### Operating system version (i.e. 20.04, 11.3, 10)

15.5

### Description

## Background

We have a test scenario where our server immediately sends a websocket protocol "ping" upon a client connecting as part of starting a heartbeat. Currently the client created by `.injectWS()` does NOT register `ws.on("ping", () => ws.pong())` causing this ping to be lost.

## Attempted Workarounds

We've tried immediately registering it, but this causes a race condition as we don't get access to the websocket until after the connection has completed:

```ts
const ws = server.injectWS("/ws")
ws.on("ping", () => ws.pong())
```

Given the flakiness of this, we added a server side delay to starting the heartbeat. This is not ideal but is a sufficient workaround until a proper fix can be done.

## Suggested Fix

It seems like a one line addition of `ws.on("ping", () => ws.pong())` could be done here where `.on("open", ...)` is already set:

https://github.com/fastify/fastify-websocket/blob/90ac47d51d7b72c186311d0c58ded1af42a92a76/index.js#L67-L70

## Impact & Risk of Change

This seems like a low impact change as no other aspects of testing the websocket outside of the built in ping/pong protocol seem to be impacted by this, as best I can tell. If that impact is still deemed too substantial then the desire to enable ping/pong could be done as part of the data handed to `.injectWS()`.

## Closing Remarks

Just wanted to say thank you for all the great work on `fustily-websocket`! We rely on it for production uses and have been extremely happy with it 😄 I'm happy to open a small PR for this if desired. 

### Link to code that reproduces the bug

https://gist.github.com/code-ape/bc6199713f9fee8415b6998db1b1f9fa

### Expected Behavior

The client created by `.injectWS()` should have `.on("ping", () => ws.pong())` set by default.
comments:
I do not convince we should registered the `ping` event by default. The main reason is that we do not automatically reply on `ping` in our handler.

In order to due with this issue, we can provide hooks option for you to manage the lifecycle.
For example,
```js
const ws = server.injectWS("/ws", {}, {
  onInit: (ws) => {}, // used when initial the websocket
  onOpen: (ws) => {} // used when before resolve the open event
})
```

The server immediately sends a websocket protocol "ping" upon a client connecting as part of starting a heartbeat, but the client does not register the `ping` event by default.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The expected behavior is for the client created by `.injectWS()` to have `.on("ping", () => ws.pong())` set by default, ensuring that the ping is not lost when the client connects to the server.
summary.attemptedFixes: The suggested fix is to add `ws.on("ping", () => ws.pong())` where `.on("open", ...)` is already set in the `index.js` file. The fix can be implemented by providing a hooks option for managing the lifecycle of the websocket, allowing users to register events like `ping` and `pong`.

issueDTO.title: Stream names are not friendly with logging systems (mlflow, wandb, etc.)
issueDTO.description:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.

Currently, we allow descriptive stream names such as `NPP, ATMS` following a known convention in the satellite world. See [this example](https://github.com/ecmwf/WeatherGenerator/pull/328/files#diff-f893baba4f83facdfc557997e6bf4b389b927123e41035d4450fbb06e957b5f7). However, logging systems only want simple names for metrics such as `a.b.c`. where `a` is `a-zA-Z0-9-_` . It could be more but I would not push because it would break pandas column selection.

As a result, we cannot really have per-stream metrics, which would be useful for example to track how many samples are being ingested per stream. In this case it would be `streams.NPP, ATMS.count_samples` which would cause issues with WandB or MLFlow.

I see 3 ways forward:

- magic: conversion of `NPP, ATMS` to camelCase `NppAtms` for example
- convention: only allow names that follow the convention above and return error instead
- extra info: when defining a stream name, require a user to set an `stream_id` as a unique machine-ready identifier (for example `NPP_ATMS`)

In any case, I believe this name should be `a-zA-Z0-9_` (no _ to prevent weird issues with databases or pandas)

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/47964380/pandas-dataframe-column-naming-conventions



Do you have any thoughts on that?

### Describe the solution you'd like

_No response_

### Describe alternatives you've considered

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

### Organisation

_No response_
comments: Can't we use "NPP, ATMS" as the user friendly identifier and convert automagically to the machine friendly form (like NppAtms) that is typically hidden from the user?
That sounds good to me. Explicit is always better than Implicit, but I do not have strong opinions for this naming convention.

> That sounds good to me. Explicit is always better than Implicit, but I do not have strong opinions for this naming convention.

For the user format: for obs, "[PLATFORM, INSTRUMENT]" is standard. For the internal format, camel case with all offending chars parsed away sounds good.
I'll start working on this

The easy part: conversion to camelcase

```
import re

def camel_case(s, regex=r"[a-zA-Z0-9]+"):
    """
    Convert a string to camelCase. Characters to omit are all not in given regular expression.
    
    :param s: Input string
    :param regex: Regular expression defining valid characters in words
    :return: CamelCase version of the input string
    """
    # Split the string into words based on characters not in regular expression
    re_pattern = re.compile(regex)
    words = re_pattern.findall(s)

    if not words:
        return ""
    
    # Capitalize the first letter of each word
    camel_cased = ''.join(word.capitalize() for word in words)
    
    return camel_cased
```

`camel_case("NPP, ATMS")` gives `NppAtms`

@tjhunter  Is retrieving the original string desired or will we just store a copy? And where would you do the conversion?

We should retain the human readable form (like "NPP, ATMS") if possible and additionally store the machine friendly version.

For the function documentation, can we use the agreed on style.

summary.main: Stream names are not friendly with logging systems (mlflow, wandb, etc.) because they only allow simple names for metrics, whereas the WeatherGenerator currently allows descriptive stream names following a known convention in the satellite world, which causes issues with WandB or MLFlow.

# Add `atbash` cipher as an `encoding` probe

Probes in the `encoding` module try to attack the target by providing a payload that's encoded in a certain way. The intent is to check whether the encoding allows bypassing alignment or fine-tuning in the model.

For this issue,

* implement `encoding.InjectAtbash`
* Add docs and testing for this class

For info on what atbash is and suggestions of how to implement it, see:
 
* https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atbash
* https://blog.finxter.com/5-best-ways-to-implement-atbash-cipher-in-python/

issueDTO.title: Add support for ament_cmake_python in ros2 pkg create
issueDTO.description:
## Feature request

#### Feature description

ROS2 CLI allows creating packages for `cmake`, `ament_cmake`, `ament_python`. Considering there isn't a complete example in the documentation for [ament_cmake_python](https://docs.ros.org/en/humble/How-To-Guides/Ament-CMake-Python-Documentation.html) , it would be helpful to support generating one for users. 

#### Implementation considerations

Follow best practices for using ament. 
Supply a working example with both C++ and python code. 
Ensure dependencies are exported correctly.
comments:
I have a few questions regarding the issue in my attempt to solve it: -
- Do I strictly follow the folder structure in the documentation as it seems having `include` and `src` directory like in `ament_cmake` might be better.
- Is it only for the rolling branch ?
- Any other suggestions or coding style or best practices I have to adhere to ?

Someone attempted this before; you should take a look at the PR and the discussion: https://github.com/ros2/ros2cli/pull/904.

And yes, you should target the `rolling` branch, and we can consider backporting it to other branches afterwards.

I read the discussion, so to solve the issue, rather than implement a separate `ament_cmake_python` package type, a template type of `python` must be implemented with build type `ament_cmake`.

So, what are the new requirements to solve the issue and is it still open ?

I think that's about it! It should still use `--build-type ament_cmake` because a package using `ament_cmake_python` is still a package of build type `ament_cmake`: [`ament_cmake_python` is just a set of CMake utilities for `ament_cmake` packages that contain Python code](https://docs.ros.org/en/jazzy/How-To-Guides/Ament-CMake-Python-Documentation.html). We just want to use a different template file, and we'd like for it to be selected using `--template-name python` (+ `--build-type ament_cmake`).

In summary:

1. `--build-type ament_cmake`: uses the [current template](https://github.com/ros2/ros2cli/blob/rolling/ros2pkg/ros2pkg/resource/ament_cmake/CMakeLists.txt.em)
2. `--build-type ament_cmake --template-name cmake`: uses the current template too (we assume that `--template-name cmake` is the default with `--build-type ament_cmake`)
3. `--build-type ament_cmake --template-name python`: uses a new template for `ament_cmake` packages that contain Python code and thus use `ament_cmake_python`, like the one in https://github.com/ros2/ros2cli/pull/904

This hasn't been implemented as far as I can tell, so yes this is still open!

Sorry, got caught up in the college semester, now I am working on this issue. I would like to ask that if `ament_cmake_python` is no longer a build type, then how will the `package.xml` and `CMakeLists.txt` change ? Already did rest of the changes to create directory and generate rest of the files.
The [documentation](https://docs.ros.org/en/jazzy/How-To-Guides/Ament-CMake-Python-Documentation.html) does not clarify that part.

Also, what happens to the `build-type cmake`. Build types `ament_cmake` and `cmake`  output different projects. So as per your points above, `cmake` build type should be removed.

Hi @bismuth01, @christophebedard,

I’m interested in contributing to the `ament_cmake_python` support for `ros2 pkg create` (#739). I noticed the recent discussion about using `--template-name python` with `--build-type ament_cmake` and the need for updated `package.xml` and `CMakeLists.txt` templates. Could you confirm if the issue is still open for contributions? If so, I’d like to work on implementing the Python template and testing it with a sample package containing both C++ and Python nodes.

For clarification, should the new template include a specific folder structure (e.g., `scripts/` for Python executables and `<package_name>/` for modules)? Also, are there any additional best practices or test requirements I should follow beyond what’s outlined in the ROS2 contribution guidelines?

Looking forward to your guidance!

Thanks,
Vinayak Shinde

@vinayak1729-web I'm happy to see that you want to contribute! However, someone is already working on this issue. Please take a look at some other _help wanted_/_good first issue_ issues that someone hasn't already claimed.

> Sorry, got caught up in the college semester, now I am working on this issue. I would like to ask that if `ament_cmake_python` is no longer a build type, then how will the `package.xml` and `CMakeLists.txt` change ? Already did rest of the changes to create directory and generate rest of the files. The [documentation](https://docs.ros.org/en/jazzy/How-To-Guides/Ament-CMake-Python-Documentation.html) does not clarify that part.
> 
> Also, what happens to the `build-type cmake`. Build types `ament_cmake` and `cmake` output different projects. So as per your points above, `cmake` build type should be removed.

@bismuth01 sorry for the late reply.

I am talking about the `ament_cmake` build type here, not the `cmake` build type. The `cmake` build type can be left as-is.

There is currently only one "version" of the template files used for the `ament_cmake` build type. What we want to do here is to have another version of the template files that uses `ament_cmake_python`, similar to [what's described in the docs](https://docs.ros.org/en/rolling/How-To-Guides/Ament-CMake-Python-Documentation.html).

In my comment above (https://github.com/ros2/ros2cli/issues/739#issuecomment-2810590122), I proposed to select the version of the template files using a new `--template-name` option, which could only be used with `--build-type ament_cmake`, since it only applies to the `ament_cmake` build type:

1. `--build-type ament_cmake`: uses the [current template](https://github.com/ros2/ros2cli/blob/rolling/ros2pkg/ros2pkg/resource/ament_cmake/CMakeLists.txt.em)
2. `--build-type ament_cmake --template-name cmake`: uses the current template too (we assume that `--template-name cmake` is the default with `--build-type ament_cmake`)
3. `--build-type ament_cmake --template-name python`: uses a new template for `ament_cmake` packages that contain Python code and thus use `ament_cmake_python`, like the one in https://github.com/ros2/ros2cli/pull/904

The files for the two different versions (1&2 vs 3 above) are _almost_ the same, except for these extra lines in the template files used when we select `--template-name python`:

1.  `CMakeLists.txt`:
    1. Add `find_package(ament_cmake_python REQUIRED)` at the top, [as shown here](https://docs.ros.org/en/rolling/How-To-Guides/Ament-CMake-Python-Documentation.html#using-ament-cmake-python)
    2. Add `ament_python_install_package(${PROJECT_NAME})` before the tests, [as shown here](https://docs.ros.org/en/rolling/How-To-Guides/Ament-CMake-Python-Documentation.html#using-ament-cmake-python)
    3. Add some code for Python tests inside `if(BUILD_TESTING) ... endif()`, [as shown here](https://docs.ros.org/en/rolling/How-To-Guides/Ament-CMake-Python-Documentation.html#using-ament-cmake-pytest)
1. `package.xml`:
    1. Add a `buildtool_depend` on `ament_cmake_python`, [as shown here](https://docs.ros.org/en/rolling/How-To-Guides/Ament-CMake-Python-Documentation.html#using-ament-cmake-python)
    2. Add a `test_depend` on `ament_cmake_pytest`, [as shown here](https://docs.ros.org/en/rolling/How-To-Guides/Ament-CMake-Python-Documentation.html#using-ament-cmake-pytest)

Does that help? Since the files are almost the same, you could have one set of template files and only include the `ament_cmake_python` parts I described above using some `@[if ...]@` conditions in the `.em` template file _if_ the user selects ` --template-name python`.

If you've already made some changes in a branch, you could create a PR and we can discuss there.

@christophebedard I am almost done with the changes, I just want to know on how to handle node name and library name ?
Do I take those arguments in consideration and if yes, then which kind should be generated (python or cmake) ?

The changes include adding `find_package(ament_cmake_python REQUIRED)` at the top, `ament_python_install_package(${PROJECT_NAME})` before the tests, and some code for Python tests inside `if(BUILD_TESTING) ... endif()`. The documentation does not clarify the changes required for `package.xml` and `CMakeLists.txt` templates, and the contributor is asked to follow best practices and test requirements outlined in the ROS2 contribution guidelines.

issueDTO.title: Question about LAM stage 2 didn't use text encoder
issueDTO.description:
I know there are some instructions in the paper that in stage1 the tasks are already decoupled, but the question is, why? Why doesn't LAM stage 2 have a text encoder? What if I want to do some further complicated tasks in stage2 specifically in the Nav task, for example, I need to specify the go - to target in the nav task?

Is there any further reason why stage 2 didn't have a text input condition?
comments: Finally, someone is asking this! Yes, keeping the text input seems more reasonable. Our final version is primarily an empirical choice. Initially, we kept the text input for the LAM encoder in stage 2 but found that dropping it performs better. You can try both designs in your own setting to see which one works best.

I'm very curious about this issue as well. 
- The 1st stage is called **task-irrelevant** while task instructions are provided. 
- The 2nd stage is called **task-centric** while task information is not given.
What are the reasons behind those terminologies?

Thanks for bringing this up! During the first stage of training, the strong information bottleneck created by the VQ-VAE codebook forces the learned latent actions to capture only the information not inferable from task instructions—resulting in task-irrelevant latent actions.

In the second stage, with these task-irrelevant latents frozen, the newly initialized latent actions are trained to replace the role of language, allowing them to learn task-centric dynamics.

This also explains why, in naive latent action learning approaches like LAPA and Genie, latent action tokens mostly encode motion/dynamics—since texture information is already preserved from previous frames for future frame prediction in the decoder.

If your goal is to learn task-relevant tokens, why not directly use contrastive learning to encode those tokens and perform a soft alignment with the text instruction features? Have you tried this approach? It seems like a more straightforward way to achieve your objective.

@retsuh-bqw Thanks for your detailed explanation.

To support your claims, I think it would be helpful to demonstrate what kind of behavior the latent actions actually exhibit. Have you tried comparing them in a way similar to LAPA Figure 13? Or perhaps visualizing the reconstructions like in LAPA Figure 14?

repository.name: UniVLA

summary.attemptedFixes: The fix can be implemented by providing a detailed explanation of the reasoning behind not using a text encoder in LAM stage 2, possibly including a demonstration of the behavior of the latent actions.

issueDTO.title: [Feature Request]: Configurable Connection Retries for DB and Redis
issueDTO.description:
### 🧭 Epic

**Title:** Configurable Connection-Retry Back-off for Database & Redis  
**Goal:** Prevent gateway startup failures caused by slow-to-start services by making retry limits and intervals fully configurable. 
**Why now:** In containerised deployments Postgres (or any other SQL backend) and Redis often take several seconds to accept TCP connections. Today the gateway gives up on the first failure, crashing with `psycopg2.OperationalError: connection … refused`. Operators need a simple way—via environment variables, just like `DB_POOL_SIZE`, `CACHE_TYPE`, etc.—to tune how many times and how often the gateway retries before aborting.

---

### 🧭 Type of Feature

- [x] Enhancement to existing functionality

---

### 🙋‍♂️ User Story 1

**As a:** DevOps engineer running MCP Gateway in Kubernetes  
**I want:** to set `DB_MAX_RETRIES` and `DB_RETRY_INTERVAL_MS` for any SQLAlchemy-backed database  
**So that:** the application patiently waits until the database container is ready, instead of crashing and restarting in a loop

#### ✅ Acceptance Criteria

```gherkin
Scenario: Database retries during startup
Given MCP Gateway starts with DB_MAX_RETRIES=10 and DB_RETRY_INTERVAL_MS=5000
And the database is not yet ready
When the first connection attempt fails
Then the gateway should log "DB connection failed (attempt 1/10), retrying in 5 s"
And it should retry every 5 s
And after 10 failed attempts it should exit with a clear error message
```

---

### 🙋‍♂️ User Story 2

**As a:** Site Reliability Engineer using Redis caching  
**I want:** analogous knobs `REDIS_MAX_RETRIES` and `REDIS_RETRY_INTERVAL_MS`  
**So that:** the gateway’s cache layer behaves consistently with the database layer

#### ✅ Acceptance Criteria

```gherkin
Scenario: Redis retries respect custom settings
Given REDIS_MAX_RETRIES=15 and REDIS_RETRY_INTERVAL_MS=2000
And Redis is unavailable
When the cache subsystem initialises
Then it must retry up to 15 times at 2 s intervals
And surface a single aggregated error if all attempts fail
```

---

### 🙋‍♂️ User Story 3

**As a:** Platform administrator  
**I want:** sensible defaults (3 retries × 2000 ms) so I don’t have to set anything for typical installs  
**So that:** small deployments gain resilience out-of-the-box

#### ✅ Acceptance Criteria

```

Scenario: Defaults work when variables are unset
Given none of the four *_RETRIES or *_INTERVAL_MS variables are set
When the gateway cannot reach the database
Then it retries 3 times with 2 s between attempts

```

---

### 📐 Design Sketch (optional)

```mermaid
flowchart TD
subgraph Settings
ENV[".env / ENV vars"]
end
ENV --> Config[config.py load Settings]
Config -->|DB config| DBClient[SQLAlchemy Engine]
Config -->|Cache config| RedisClient[Redis Async Client]

DBClient --> RetryLogic
RedisClient --> RetryLogic

RetryLogic{{"Retry up to N timesnsleep(interval_ms)"}}
RetryLogic --> Logger
```

| Component | Change | Detail |
|----------|--------|--------|
| `config.py` | Add four `@env_settings` fields | `db_max_retries:int=3`, `db_retry_interval_ms:int=2000`, `redis_max_retries:int=3`, `redis_retry_interval_ms:int=2000` |
| `db.py` | Wrap DB connect logic in retry loop | Use `asyncio.sleep()` for interval |
| Redis cache init | Retry connect with same config | Applies if `CACHE_TYPE=redis` |
| Logging | One log per retry attempt | Include attempt count and retry delay |
| README | Add env var docs | Match style of existing DB/Redis config

---

### 🔗 MCP Standards Check

- [x] No protocol-level breaking changes
- [x] Follows existing env var config conventions
- [ ] Deviations: none

---

### 🔄 Alternatives Considered

| Alternative | Pros | Cons |
|------------|------|------|
| `docker-compose` healthcheck + `depends_on` | Simple for local dev | Doesn’t help bare-metal or k8s |
| Exponential back-off | Faster in some cases | Adds complexity |
| Gunicorn retry preload script | Works for some runners | Not general-purpose

---

### 📓 Additional Context

- Mirrors retry pattern used in `max_tool_retries`
- Naming aligned with `DB_POOL_SIZE`, `CACHE_TYPE`, etc.
- Ensure this is then changed in the helm chart.

Example configuration:

```bash
export DB_MAX_RETRIES=10
export DB_RETRY_INTERVAL_MS=5000
export REDIS_MAX_RETRIES=10
export REDIS_RETRY_INTERVAL_MS=5000
```

issueDTO.title: [Feature Request]: Test MCP Server Connectivity Debugging Tool
issueDTO.description:
### 🧭 Epic

**Title:** Test Server Connectivity from Gateway UI  
**Goal:** Help administrators debug server setup issues by interactively sending custom HTTP requests to configured MCP servers  
**Why now:** When adding a new MCP server, it's often unclear if a given URL or endpoint is live, secure, or responding as expected. Today, users must use curl/Postman to debug. This feature allows testing any method, path, headers, or body directly from the Gateway UI.

---

### 🧭 Type of Feature

- [x] New functionality

---

### 🙋‍♂️ User Story 1

**As a:** Gateway administrator  
**I want:** to send custom HTTP requests (GET, POST, etc.) to any path on the server I'm configuring  
**So that:** I can debug connectivity, validate endpoint behavior, and inspect the actual server responses before saving

#### ✅ Acceptance Criteria

```gherkin
Scenario: Send a custom request to the server before saving
  Given I am adding a new server in the Gateway UI
  And I enter a server base URL
  When I click "Test Server"
  Then I should be able to:
    - Choose an HTTP method (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, etc.)
    - Enter a relative path (e.g., /health)
    - Provide optional headers and request body
  When I click "Send"
  Then the system sends the request to base_url + path
  And I should see:
    - HTTP status code
    - Total response time (latency)
    - Response body (pretty-printed JSON if possible)
```

---

### 📐 Design Sketch (optional)

```
+-------------------- Gateway UI ---------------------+
| Server URL: https://api.example.com                |
|                                                    |
| [ Test Server ] ← opens test panel                 |
+----------------------------------------------------+

⇣ click

+-------------------- Test Server --------------------+
| Method: [GET ▼]                                     |
| Path: /version                                      |
| Headers (JSON): { "Authorization": "Bearer xyz" }  |
| Body (JSON): { "foo": "bar" } (for POST, PUT...)   |
| [ Send ]                                            |
|                                                    |
| ⇣ Results                                           |
| ➤ Status: 200 OK                                    |
| ➤ Latency: 120 ms                                   |
| ➤ Response:                                         |
| {                                                   |
|   "version": "1.0.0",                               |
|   "status": "healthy"                               |
| }                                                   |
+-----------------------------------------------------+
```

---

### 🔗 MCP Standards Check

- [x] No impact on protocol or server discovery logic
- [x] Safe, diagnostic-only feature
- [x] Follows existing conventions for JSON and HTTP tooling

---

### 🔄 Alternatives Considered

| Option | Pros | Cons |
|--------|------|------|
| Predefined test list (/health, /version) | Simpler UI | Not flexible, less useful for real-world debugging |
| Silent background ping | No UI work | Less control, can miss issues with specific headers/methods |
| CLI-only debug tools | No frontend work | Fragments experience, not user-friendly

---

### 📓 Additional Context

- This is especially useful when:
  - Testing authenticated or proxied servers
  - Verifying custom response structures
  - Diagnosing CORS or TLS errors from browser context
- Future enhancements could include:
  - Copy-as-curl button
  - History of past test requests
  - Auto-fill common headers like `Content-Type: application/json`

issueDTO.title: [Docs]: Add documentation for using mcp-cli with MCP Gateway
issueDTO.description:
### 📚 Documentation Issue Summary  
Please add documentation for using [`mcp-cli`](https://github.com/chrishayuk/mcp-cli) as a client with MCP Gateway.

`mcp-cli` is a Python-based command-line interface for interacting with MCP-compliant servers. Adding it to the docs will help users test, debug, or script against MCP Gateway instances without needing to use a browser-based tool. It's especially useful for automation, CI, or quick terminal-driven interaction.

---

### 📍 Location of the Problem
Suggested new page: `docs/docs/using/clients/mcp-cli.md`  
Also link it from the `.pages` file.

---

### ✏️ Type of Issue  

- [ ] Typo or formatting issue  
- [ ] Outdated or incorrect information  
- [x] Missing explanation or example  
- [x] Unclear instructions  
- [ ] Other (explain below)

---

### 🧩 Additional Notes (optional)  

Include usage for Bearer token auth and support for `mcpgateway-wrapper` flows (e.g. using a local wrapper for dev testing).
comments:
@crivetimihai, my plan to address this is:

1. Create a new documentation page at docs/docs/using/clients/mcp-cli.md that:

   - Introduces mcp-cli as a Python CLI tool for interacting with MCP Gateway.
   - Explains how to use it with Bearer token authentication, referencing the MCP_AUTH_TOKEN environment variable.
   - Describes how to use it with mcpgateway-wrapper for local development/testing, including setting MCP_SERVER_CATALOG_URLS and running the wrapper.
   - Provides example commands and configuration snippets based on the README content and typical usage patterns.
   - Mentions the stdio transport and its role in enabling clients without SSE support.

2. Update the docs/docs/using/.pages file to add a link to this new mcp-cli documentation page for discoverability.

3. Verify the instructions by testing mcp-cli usage with MCP Gateway and mcpgateway-wrapper locally if feasible.

let me know your thoughts and I can start working on it.
Sounds good, thanks! You can also close #19 as well, similar ticket, just cover it in the same documentation.

issueDTO.title: [Docs]: Add Developer Guide for MCP CLI Integration and Usage
issueDTO.description:
### 📚 Documentation Issue Summary

The documentation currently lacks a guide on how to use the new `mcp-cli` [(Model Context Protocol Command Line Interface)](https://github.com/chrishayuk/mcp-cli), which enables rich, scriptable, and interactive access to MCP Gateway-compatible servers and tools.

---

### 📍 Location of the Problem

> Suggested location: `docs/docs/clients/mcp-cli.md`

---

### ✏️ Type of Issue

* [x] Missing explanation or example
* [x] Unclear instructions

---

### 💡 Suggested Fix or Clarification

Create a new documentation page that mirrors the structure used for the Copilot integration guide, including:

#### ✅ Overview

* Introduce `mcp-cli` as a Pyodide-compatible, terminal-native CLI for interacting with MCP Gateway servers.
* Mention multi-mode support: chat, interactive shell, command-line automation.

#### 🛠 Prerequisites

* Python ≥ 3.11
* `uv` (optional)
* MCP Gateway running locally or remotely
* JWT or Basic Auth credentials

#### 🔧 Installation

```bash
git clone https://github.com/chrishayuk/mcp-cli
cd mcp-cli
pip install -e ".[cli,dev]"
```

#### ⚙️ Configuring Your Server

Create a `server_config.json`:

```json
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "mcpgateway-wrapper": {
      "command": "python3",
      "args": ["-m", "mcpgateway.wrapper"],
      "env": {
        "MCP_AUTH_TOKEN": "<your-token>",
        "MCP_SERVER_CATALOG_URLS": "http://localhost:4444/servers/1",
        "MCP_TOOL_CALL_TIMEOUT": "120"
      }
    }
  }
}
```

#### 🧪 Basic Usage

* **Chat Mode**:

  ```bash
  uv run mcp-cli chat --server=localhost
  ```
* **Tool Listing**:

  ```bash
  uv run mcp-cli tools list {} --server=localhost
  ```
* **Tool Invocation**:

  ```bash
  uv run mcp-cli tools call {} --server=localhost
  ```

Include tips for resolving `"Missing argument 'KWARGS'"` errors by adding `{}` or using `--`.

#### 📝 Features to Highlight

* Auto-discovered tools from MCP Gateway
* OpenAI/Anthropic/Ollama provider switching
* JSON export for conversation history
* Mode comparison (chat vs. interactive vs. cmd)

---

### 🧩 Additional Notes

The `mcp-cli` documentation is hosted at [https://github.com/chrishayuk/mcp-cli](https://github.com/chrishayuk/mcp-cli). Leverage this for command examples and installation options.

Include both stido and potential SSE setup (if supported).

issueDTO.title: Refactor PostgreSQLBinaryProtocolValue related test cases
issueDTO.description:
`PostgreSQLBinaryProtocolValue` implementations all have 3 methods:
- getColumnLength
- read
- write

Now, some unit test classes have three methods: 
- assertGetColumnLength
- assertRead
- assertWrite 

others have only one test method: `assertNewInstance`


Please split these `assertNewInstance` into `assertGetColumnLength`, `assertRead` and `assertWrite`.

### task list
- [ ] PostgreSQLBoolBinaryProtocolValueTest
- [ ] PostgreSQLBoolBinaryProtocolValueTest
- [ ] PostgreSQLTimeBinaryProtocolValueTest

issueDTO.title: Windows: Long filename detection
issueDTO.description:
Re: https://discuss.python.org/t/pep-773-a-python-installation-manager-for-windows/77900/160

https://github.com/pypa/pip/blob/24f4600851bbb3d7f22aed0ba6b1e2dcc4973412/src/pip/_internal/commands/install.py#L777-L791

```py
try:
    Path('a' * 300 + '.txt').touch()
except OSError as e:
    exc = e
```

This gives exc as `OSError(22, 'Invalid argument')`, where `exc.errno == errno.EINVAL`, rather than `ENOENT`.

Python 3.13.2; Windows 11

A
comments: What about a path with a few slashes in it? I vaguely remember that long paths and long names are treated differently. (Sorry, I'm a long way from the nearest Windows machine or I'd just check myself.)

It turns out I do have long paths enabled (via the registry rather than group policy), sorry for the false report. The problem seen here is when the filename itself is 255 characters or longer, which does still occur on PyPI.

```pycon
>>> Path('a/'*300).mkdir(parents=True, exist_ok=True)
>>> Path('a/'*300 + 'a'*251 + '.txt').touch()
>>> Path('a/'*300 + 'a'*252 + '.txt').touch()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<input>", line 1, in <module>
  File "...\Lib\pathlib\__init__.py", line 1010, in touch
    fd = os.open(self, flags, mode)
OSError: [Errno 22] Invalid argument: 'a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\a\\aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa.txt'
```

Yeah, there are a few different errors that can occur due to long paths. But that particular one is due to a long _segment_, which is still limited even with the OS setting changed.

You might want to look at the `.winerror` attribute (if it's there). Windows has much more fine grained error codes than POSIX, and we map a lot of different errors to ENOENT and EINVAL. Still pretty sure you can't tell specifically that the path was too long, though. Catching the error and checking the path argument that was passed in is the "best" way (it's not great).
PRs are welcome :)
Hi @ichard26, I've put together a PR for this issue. If you have a moment, I’d really appreciate it if you could take a look and provide any feedback or suggestions.

issueDTO.title: CLI: Add `--environment` flag to `keyshade run` command
issueDTO.description:
## Description

As a user, I would like to be able to configure my application to run with various environments without needing to change the environment slug in `keyshade.json`. It would be nice to have a `--environment <slug>` flag that would override the currently set environment in `keyshade.json`. 

Usecase:
```sh
keyshade run --environment stage-0 "npm run start"
```

## Solution

- Update the `run.command.ts` file in `apps/cli` package to accept an optional `environment` flag
- If the flag is specified, we would like this value to take precedence over the one specified in `keyshade.json`

issueDTO.title: Benchmark files missing when installed
issueDTO.description:
For some reason, I couldn't install the package straight from pypi using `pip install docext`
```
ERROR: Could not find a version that satisfies the requirement docext (from versions: none)
ERROR: No matching distribution found for docext
```

When I install the package from source in **non-editable mode**, the benchmark script fails. 

Steps to reproduce:
```bash
git clone https://github.com/NanoNets/docext.git
cd docext
pip install .
python docext/benchmark/benchmark/py
```

I get this error - `ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'docext.benchmark.metrics'`
Running in editable mode (`pip install -e`) works fine. I think this is from the missing top level `__init__.py` in the `docext/benchmark/metrics` folder.
comments: 👋 Welcome! Thanks for opening your first issue. If you'd like to take a crack at fixing it, feel free to open a pull request — otherwise, we'll take a look as soon as we can!

Yeah. The benchmark code is supposed to run with a local setup, since there is a config file that you need to edit to select a different config. If we want to run it with the PyPI package, we need to add all those configs as args. Feel free to raise a PR if you are interested in contributing.
